basics.name: Annika Salmi
basics.summary: MPhil at the University of Cambridge

education.area: planetary science and Life in the Universe

courses: Research semester in Fall 2020, studying dust around supermassive black holes
education.thesis: Correlating mapped nuclear dust with AGN obscuration

work.name: Starfish Space
work.summary: Worked on physics simulations and on-orbit data analysis.
highlights: Developed a tool to analyze on-orbit data for satellite location, achieving 95% simulation accuracy.
Modeled low Earth orbit physics to refine the coefficient of drag, discovering a lower-than-expected value.
Enhanced synthetic training images for navigation models by simulating hot pixels, cosmic rays, and blurring.
Designed a pipeline to process and clean on-orbit data for ground analysis.
Improved simulation model performance by 30% by optimizing algorithms and tailoring cloud tools in Python and C++.

work.name: Urry Lab, Yale University
work.summary: Conducted research on galaxy dust distributions to analyze active galactic nuclei (AGN) obscuration.
highlights: Mapped dust distributions of 109 galaxies with AGN to resolve X-ray radiation obscuration.
Developed an algorithm combining infrared and optical Hubble images to visualize galactic dust.
Created a GitHub package to generate attenuation (dust) maps of galaxies.
Presented findings at the Mellon Forum and received funding from the Richter Memorial Fund.

work.name: Newburgh Lab, Yale University
work.summary: Analyzed data from the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME) to calibrate telescope accuracy.
highlights: Generated frequency-intensity graphs of bright stars to identify calibration errors in CHIME telescope data.
Calibrated 5 frequency channels with inaccurate measurements using results from Cedar supercomputer.
Funded by the Richter Memorial Fund.

work.name: Peabody Museum, Yale University
work.summary: Supported research and curation activities in the field of paleobotany at the Peabody Museum.

volunteer.organization: Institute of Astronomy, University of Cambridge
volunteer.summary: Volunteered during public science nights, engaging with attendees to explain astronomy topics.
Led Yale’s astronomy outreach group, creating engaging educational experiences for local students.
highlights: Wrote and presented planetarium shows for New Haven students.
Taught Yale students effective science communication techniques.

volunteer.summary: Authored astronomy-related popular science articles for Yale’s student newspaper.
highlights: Published additional pieces in outlets such as Matador Network and Study Breaks.

volunteer.summary: Facilitated visitor engagement and interactive science education at a leading hands-on museum.
highlights: Explained exhibits to visitors and led public dissections.

projects.title: exo-atm-predict
projects.description: Select a discovered exoplanet and the tool tells you what the most 'likely' characteristics of its atmosphere will be, based on what astronomers have already observed. Very biased; can be useful to see what those biases are. Specifically examining M-dwarfs with results.

projects.title: exo-venus-evolution
projects.description: Model the evolution of 'exo-Venuses' over their geological history, using Venus and exo-Venus data.

projects.title: alignpy
projects.description: Built a tool that locally downloads FITS files of astronomical objects, specified by filter and catalog. Once they are downloaded, the image files can be aligned and plotted via addition, subtraction, or division.

items: Paul K. Richter and Evalyn E. Cook Richter Memorial Fund
Paul K. Richter and Evalyn E. Cook Richter Memorial Fund
National Science Foundation funding to go to Antarctica
